A simple method for preparing imidazolium-based polymer as solid catalyst for Suzuki-Miyaura reaction Weiqiang Zhang a c Liangyi Peng a Chunyan Deng a Yingxue Zhang b Hao Qian a ⁎ a College of Material Science and Engineering, Huaqiao University, XiaMen, Fujian, 361021, China College of Material Science and Engineering Huaqiao University XiaMen Fujian 361021 China b College of Communication Science and Engineering, Huaqiao University, XiaMen, Fujian, 361021, China College of Communication Science and Engineering Huaqiao University XiaMen Fujian 361021 China c Key Laboratory of Ecological Environment and Information Atlas, Fujian Provincial University, China Key Laboratory of Ecological Environment and Information Atlas Fujian Provincial University China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Polymers containing the structure of N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) have attracted much interest due to their superior complexing ability to metal ions and good recyclability, which make them promising candidates as solid supporters. Herein, we developed an easy method to synthesize polyimidazolium chloride salt (PImCl) via one-step method in mild conditions. After PImCl was chelated with palladium chloride in 3-chloropyridine, this NHC-Pd polymer was employed as the solid catalyst for Suzuki reactions of aryl bromides and phenylboronic acid. The catalytic activity of the NHC-Pd polymer was high for many different substrates. Moreover, the Suzuki reaction of 4-bromoanisole with phenylboronic acid could be catalyzed by this NHC-Pd polymer in mild conditions. Furthermore, this solid catalyst could be easily isolated by centrifugal separation. After several recycling runs, the catalytic activity decreased little. Compared with the conventional methods, this method was much simpler and more efficient, which showed enormous potential in preparing new heterogeneous supporter of porous polyimidazolium chloride salt. Keywords Polyimidazolium chloride salt One-step reaction Solid supporter Catalytic activity Suzuki-Miyaura reaction 1 Introduction Great progress has been made in the field of N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) in the last two decades. Although Öfele [1] and Wanzlick [2] firstly described NHC in the late 1960s, Arduengo successfully synthesized the stable NHC until 1991 [3]. In recent years, the structure of bulky NHCs has received great attention because it can improve catalytic activity of NHC-Pd complex [4–6]. Several groups such as Glorius [7], Nolan [8], Matt [9], Krinsky [10] have made great development in this field. Compared with the conventional phosphine ligands, NHCs are less sensitive to air and temperature [11] due to their strong interaction with metal center [12,13]. Thus, the preparation and application of NHCs have increasingly received attention in field of homogeneous catalysis as the ligands for transition metals [14], for example palladium, ruthenium, nickel and gold. Although a multitude of cross-coupling reactions have been successfully performed using NHC-metal complexes, the catalyst systems are usually homogeneous. High costs and efforts, sophisticated equipment and tedious processes made the complete separation of the catalyst difficult. Therefore, heterogeneous catalyst systems are being exploiting to fit in with green chemistry. While the structure of NHCs is being optimizing, the immobilization process of NHC compounds (NHC precursors or NHC-metal complexes) is experiencing continuous diversification [15]. Since Hermann firstly reported the immobilization of NHC-Pd complex for Heck reaction in 2000 [16]. Various supporting materials have been applied to immobilize NHC compounds, including silica [17–20], carbon [21–23], polymer [20,24–28], metal oxide [29–31] and metal nanoparticles (NPs) [32–34] (Fig. 1 ). However, among these systems prepared by supporting materials, few catalysts achieved high loading of NHC compounds [15]. Especially, when the reaction occurs on the surface of the solid catalyst in heterogeneous catalysis, the abundant catalytic sites might be much helpful to improve the catalytic activity of the whole catalyst [35,36]. Therefore, it becomes much more necessary to increase the anchor sites on the carriers for improving the loading of NHC compounds. Thus, the porous materials, especially mesoporous silica materials [37–39], were widely used as the solid supporters. But, the loading of NHC compounds still leaves much to be desired. Low loading efficiency of NHC compounds results from many factors such as the number of anchor sites of supporting materials, reaction conditions, or the structure of NHC compounds15. Although many groups have made significant contributions towards the immobilization of NHC ligands, the difficulty in forming the effective linker between the NHC compounds and supporters greatly limited its immobilization. Of particular interest are the recent attempts at preparing NHC-based metal organic frameworks (MOFs) for use in heterogeneous Suzuki-Miyaura reaction [40–42]. Wu reported NHC-Pd-based MOF catalyst, which showed high catalytic activity in Suzuki-Miyaura and Heck reaction [43]. In contrast with traditional supporting materials, MOFs could extremely improve the loading capacity of NHC units. In recent years, significant efforts have been devoted towards developing covalent organic framework (COF) materials as the solid supporters [44–47]. In the structure of imidazolium-based COF materials, the main chains are linked with covalent bonds, resulting in its high stability even under rigorous conditions [48,49]. Meanwhile, the loading of NHC units was effectively improved because the responding imidazolium monomers were directly synthesized into the solid supporter. These advantages highlight their potential as the supporters of heterogeneous catalysts. However, the synthetic pathways of the imidazolium-based polymers were rather tedious and complicated, which greatly limited the popularization of imidazolium-based polymers. In order to increase the loading of NHC units on solid supporter, we intended to prepare imidazolium-based polymer, which contained the NHC units on the responding polymeric backbone. While being enlightened by the previously reported one-step method of main-chain imidazolium-containing polymers [50,51], we knew that it remained challenging to select starting materials for the formation of solid supporter. It was anticipated that the rigid part of aromatic amine might improve the insolubility of imidazolium-based polymer compared with polymer ionic liquid (PIL). Therefore, 1,4-diaminobenzene was made the focus of our study. In the purpose of precisely controlling the monomer stoichiometry ratio, paraformaldehyde was employed in one-step method to prepare imidazolium-based polymer. Inspired by this good result, we prepared NHC-Pd polymer and studied its application in heterogeneous Suzuki-Miyaura reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Paraformaldehyde was obtained from XiLong Chemical. 1,4-diaminobenzene, glyoxal solution, palladium chloride, 3-chloropyridine and potassium tert-butoxide were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. 2.2 Experimental protocols for the synthesis of PImCl and NHC-Pd polymer 2.2.1 Preparation of PImCl In one vial, paraformaldehyde (195mg, 6.5mmol) was dissolved with stirring in a solution of 4M HCl in 1,4-dioxane (2mL). Another vial was charged with the corresponding glyoxal of 40wt% in H2O (725mg, 5mmol). In a beakerflask, 1,4-diaminobenzene (504mg, 5mmol) was dissolved in 40mL dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). After the solutions in the three glasswares were mixed together, the reaction mixture was stirred for 48h at room temperature. Then, the product (PImCl) was filtered out as the brown precipitate (690mg, 77%), which was successively washed with THF, distilled water and methanol. 1H NMR (500MHz, DCOOD [ppm]): δ =8.29 (s, 1H); 8.16 (br, 2H); 7.90 (br, 4H) (Fig. S1). 2.2.2 Preparation of NHC-Pd polymer To PImCl (500mg) solution, an excess of potassium tert-butoxide (8.4mmol) was added. After stirring for 48hours, 3-chloropydine (12mL) and an excess of palladium chloride (504mg) were added into the solution. Then, the reaction mixture was heated to 60°C and kept stirring for 48h under argon atmosphere. The dark precipitate (NHC-Pd polymer) was isolated by filtration. The careful washing was carried out with THF, distilled water and methanol. 2.3 Catalysis of NHC-Pd polymer in Suzuki–Miyaura reaction A pyrex tube was charged with aryl bromide (1mmol), phenylboronic acid (1.2mmol),K2CO3 (2mmol), palladium catalyst (1mmol%) and mixture of ethanol and distilled water (4mL, v:v=1:1). The reaction mixture was stirred at 70°C for 12h under argon atmosphere. After cooled to room temperature, the resulting reaction mixture was added with chloromethane (3mL) and internal standard substance (20μL n-hexadecane). The mixture was completely shook for 10min, and then the organic layer was collected. The organic layer was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The product yield was determined by gas chromatography (GC). 2.4 Recyclability test of NHC-Pd polymer 4-bromoanisole (1mmol), phenylboronic acid (1.2mmol), palladium catalyst (5 mmol%), K2CO3 (2mmol) in C2H5OH/H2O (4mL, v:v=1:1) was heated at 70°C for 12h under argon atmosphere. The catalyst was then collected by centrifugal separation and then washed with distilled water, ethanol, CHCl3 and dried at 40°C overnight under air atmosphere. The dried catalyst was reused again to catalyze the reaction. 2.5 Characterization 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of PImCl were recorded on a Bruker Avance III 500MHz spectrometer. The structure of PImCl was analyzed by the attenuated total reflection-infrared (Nicolet iS50). The intrinsic viscosity of PImCl was measured with an Ubbelohde-type capillary viscometer (IVS300-6). The morphology of NHC-Pd polymer was observed by scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi S-4800). The content of palladium in NHC-Pd polymer was determined by energy dispersive spectrometer (Hitachi S-4800) and atomic absorption spectroscopy (Perkin-Elm 1100B). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of NHC-Pd polymer was measured on the spectrometer (Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi). The XRD pattern was carried out from 20° to 80° at the scanning rate of 10°/min on the spectrometer (Rigaku SmartLab). Size distribution of NHC-Pd polymer was analyzed on a laser particle analyzer (Beckman LS13320). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out from 308K to 1073K at the heating rate of 10°C/min using TGA-50H. N2 adsorption experiment was carried out on Autosorb-iQ at 77K. Yields were determined by gas chromatography (Agilent 7890B). 3 Results and discussion Typically, the low loading of NHC units on supporters might be attributed to the difficulty of solid synthesis and covalent grafting [15]. Hence, the methods of self-supporting were gradually developed to extremely increase the loading of NHC compounds. Furthermore, the distribution of the reactive centers on the supporter could be effectively controlled. However, self-supporting methods so far were much complicated, which was mainly determined by the tedious synthetic steps of the NHC-based monomers. Synthesis of bis-or multi-imidazolium salts was usually go through several steps. Therefore, these MOF materials were prepared via more than three steps. Compared with MOFs, some COF materials were obtained by metal-catalyzed reactions or electrochemical polymerization of NHC precursors. However, synthesis of the NHC precursors is a multistep process. In comparison with well-developed self-supporting methods for the preparation of polymer-supported NHC compounds, we synthesized imidazolium-based main-chain polymer through a simple one-step method. 3.1 A simple method to polymerize polyimidazolium chloride salt Very recent studies showed that polyimidazolium salts (PIMs) could be prepared via one-step method [50,51] and two-step method [52,53], respectively. However, in contrast to preparation of polyimidazolium described by various groups, we decided to employ a new synthetic pathway to synthesize PIM, which was shown in Scheme 1 . Until recently, two-step method reported by Coskun [53] was strongly challenged by one-step method because it was absolutely time-consuming and tedious synthetic pathways. Despite the fact that polyimidazolium salts can be prepared via one-step method, they were polymer ionic liquids; these PIMs were prepared by aliphatic diamines, resulting in its high solubility in some solvents [50]. Subsequently, Dani prepared insoluble and porous imidazolium-based polymer based on aromatic tetramine via one-step method [51]. However, the responding synthesis and purification pathways of aromatic tetramine (starting material) were much complicated. As mentioned above, developing an easy method to synthesize imidazolium-based polymer with simple aromatic amines becomes much necessary to prepare the heterogeneous supporter containing NHC units. 1,4-diaminobenzene was selected as the monomer to synthesize the heterogeneous supporter not only because it played as the rigid part (phenyl ring) in the main chains to increase its insolubility, but also due to its easy availability and cheap cost. It is vital to emphasize that insolubility of heterogeneous supporter is much important to its separation. To increase average molecular weight of PImCl, DMSO was selected as the solvent rather than acetic acid/H2O reported by those two groups [50,51]. Depending on proposed mechanism for imidazolium ring formation reported by Dani [51], we presented synthetic mechanism of our PImCl (Scheme 2 ). As shown in Scheme 2, formaldehyde was more active than glyoxal in one-step method. Furthermore, the change of the monomer ratio had great effect on the average molecular weight of the obtained polymer in multicomponent reactions. Thus, we chose the paraformaldehyde as starting material in one-step method rather than volatile formaldehyde aqueous solution. The one-step method to synthesize PImCl was based on poly-Radziszewski reaction [50]. We prepared this PImCl via simple one-step reaction under room temperature, which was very economically feasible. The 13C cross-polarization/magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (CP/MAS NMR) spectra of PImCl was shown in Fig. 2 a. The chemical shift located at 123ppm was assigned to unsubstituted phenyl carbon C1, which overlapped with the chemical shift of C3 [51,54]. The chemical shift at around 135ppm was related to the imidazolium salt carbon (C4) [10,54,55]. A signal appeared at around 149ppm can be assigned to substituted C2 [40,42,51,54]. The structure of PImCl was also analyzed by the attenuated total reflection-infrared (ATR-IR, Fig. 2b). Three bands at 1654, 1605 and 1513cm−1 belonged the vibration of benzene ring skeleton. The bands at 1254 and 822cm−1 were attributed to CH out-of-plane bending and in-plane bending vibrations of the benzene ring, respectively. The band at around 1549cm−1 was ascribable to the CN stretching vibration of the imidazolium ring [47,56], which overlapped with ring in-plane antisymmetric stretching [57]. The bands at 1384 and 1064cm−1 were assigned to CN stretching vibration of imidazolium ring [58] and ring in-plane symmetric stretching [57]. As previously stated, when the monomer ratio was changed, the average molecular weight of the obtained polymer should be changed. Because PImCl was difficult to be dissolved in common solvents, formic acid was selected as its solvent. Clearly, intrinsic viscosity ([η]) was changed when the monomer ratio was changed, which was shown in Fig. 3 . According to Mark-Houwink equation: [ η ] = K M η − α [η] is dependent of the average molecular weight ( M − η ) [59–61] a direct curve and quantitative relationship have been found between the average molecular weight and intrinsic viscosity. On the basis of Fig. 3, it can be concluded that the average molecular weight was changed while intrinsic viscosity was changed. Therefore, trials of experimental values of [η] in 90% formic acid indicated the solid supporter was the polymer. In the other hand, this poly-Radziszewski reaction may be a nonstoichiometric polymerization [50,62,63] rather than the fundamental principles of A2+B2 step-growth polymerizations [64]. The obtained intrinsic viscosity ([η]) was merely 0.53 dL/g at ideal molar ratio (1,4-diaminobenzene: glyoxal: paraformaldehyde=1:1:1). An excess of paraformaldehyde led to the higher intrinsic viscosity. Particularly, high intrinsic viscosity ([η]=0.93 dL/g) was achieved when paraformaldehyde was 1.1 equivalent. However, low intrinsic viscosity ([η]=0.46 dL/g) was obtained if paraformaldehyde was 0.95 equivalent. These results again strengthened our determination to use solid paraformaldehyde rather than volatile formaldehyde aqueous solution to prepare PImCl. Remarkably, the presence of the rigid segments could extremely decrease the solubility of PImCl. Just because of its insolubility in conventional solvents, PImCl could be employed as the solid supporter for NHC-Pd polymer. After PImCl reacted with potassium tert-butoxide, N-heterocyclic carbenes in the polymer backbone could easily chelate with palladium chloride in 3-chloropyridine to form a NHC-Pd polymer. Tyndall effect could not be observed in common solvents unless there are many clusters or small particles in the solutions. In Fig. 4 a, it found that Tyndall effect was all presented in all samples, which meant that there were many small particles in the solutions. In other words, this NHC-Pd polymer was much suitable as heterogeneous catalyst because it was insoluble in these common solvents. As shown in Fig. 4b, this NHC-Pd polymer could be easily isolated from solutions through centrifugation. After the NHC-Pd polymer particles were dispersed in distilled water for 10minutes with ultrasonic dispersion, it was determined by laser particle analyzer (LS13320). Its average particle size was about 2.02μm according to Fig. 4c. This sample was prepared with 1,4-diaminobenzene (1 equiv), glyoxal (1 equiv) and paraformaldehyde (1.3 equiv). In summary, we developed a green and quick synthetic method to prepare PImCl. Notably, high loading of NHC units could be expected due to its polymeric backbone containing NHC precursors. 3.2 Catalytic activity of NHC-Pd polymer towards Suzuki-Miyaura reaction Generally, synthesizing heterogeneous NHC-Pd complex could be prepared by two strategies (i.e., by metalation of immobilized imidazolium moiety and by immobilization of NHC-Pd complex). Unlike above two strategies, our method has enormously simplified synthetic steps depending on the self-supported technology. Our NHC-Pd polymer was prepared without using any external supporter. The imidazolium groups in PImCl could be converted to carbenes when excess potassium tert-butoxide was used. The Pd content in NHC-Pd polymer was about 31.24wt%, with the introduction of a slight Pd precursor. High-content Pd in NHC-Pd polymer resulted from the coordination of Pd(II) and the emergence of Pd(0). The catalytic efficiency of this supported NHC-Pd complex was evaluated and the results were shown in Table 1 . When the amount of NHC-Pd polymer was 0.1 mmol%, the yield reached 99% in the reaction of 4-bromoanisole and phenylboronic acid. Even catalyst loading was increased to 5mmol%, the product yield change little, attributing to its high activity. We further assessed the effect of various reaction temperature on catalytic performances in green solvent (C2H5OH/H2O). As shown in Table 2 , this NHC-Pd polymer could maintain its activity in the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction under mild reaction temperature. A conversion reached 91% when the reaction temperature was kept at 30°C. Certainly, a complete conversion performed at 70°C, which was widely used in the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction. We also explored the substrates versatility of this NHC-Pd polymer in the catalysis of Suzuki-Miyaura reaction. As shown in Table 3 , the Suzuki-Miyaura reactions of phenylboronic acid with various aryl bromides provided the desirable products and gave good yields, regardless of the electron-deficient and electron-rich substituents of aryl bromides. As seen in Fig. S2, less by-product was observed in product of some Suzuki-Miyaura reactions. 3.3 Reusability of NHC-Pd polymer towards Suzuki-Miyaura reaction UV spectra of suspension of NHC-Pd polymer dispersing in ethanol was recorded, exhibiting broad and strong absorption (Fig. 5 a). After the suspension was centrifuged, the supernatant liquid was collected and analyzed by UV. The absorption corresponding to the supernatant liquid became weaker, which showed NHC-Pd polymer can be easily and effectively separated from solution with centrifugation (Fig. 5a). We found that this catalyst could be recycled at least 3 times in Suzuki-Miyaura reaction of 4-bromoanisole. But, there was a little loss of catalytic activity (Fig. 5b). It was known that bulky NHCs can enhance the reactivity and stability of NHC-Pd complexes due to their steric and electronic effect. Therefore, we supposed that our NHC-Pd polymer might be more easily suffer from ambient conditions, which led to the damage of catalytic activity after consecutive cycles. To solve this problem, the investigations on bulky NHC-Pd polymer are currently underway in our laboratory. 3.4 Characterization of NHC-Pd polymer SEM imaging in Fig. 6 showed that NHC-Pd polymer was consisted of irregular particles with the average particles size of 2μm in diameters, which was closely in line with the result of laser particle size analyzer (LS). Energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) was employed to confirm the presence of Pd. The palladium content was about 31.16wt%, which was supported by the result of atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS). XPS spectra showed that four peaks were appeared (Fig. 7 a), which were identified as Pd2+ 3d3/2 (342.9eV), Pd2+ 3d5/2 (337.5eV), Pd0 3d3/2 (340.7eV) and Pd0 3d5/2 (335.5eV) [65]. It is clear that there were two palladium species in the samples: palladium ions and palladium(0). Although we had made much effort, it was difficult to avoid the generation of Pd clusters in basic conditions [56,66]. The diffraction peaks of NHC-Pd polymer (Fig. 7b) were weak and overlapped with Pd clusters peaks [67], further indicating the presence of nanosized metallic Pd clusters. This result has been reported by some groups that Pd(II) and Pd(0) were produced together in the process of the preparation [68,69]. Thus, for our catalyst, its catalytic activity was attributed to Pd(II) and Pd(0) together. However, the intensity of Pd2+ was much higher than that of Pd0. It indicated the palladium complex might be the main active center owing to its high content in NHC-Pd polymer. In order to explore its stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was employed and the result was shown in Fig. 8 a. When weight loss reached 10%, the temperature was 206°C. The amount of remains was still 37.53wt% after heated to 800°C, owing to its high Pd content. N2 adsorption experiment showed that the BET surface of NHC-Pd polymer was found to be 9.02m2/g (Fig. S3). In Fig. 8b, the isotherm linear plot of NHC-Pd polymer appeared hysteresis loop, which implied the presence of mesopores and irregular pore structure. However, adsorption quantity sharply rose in the relative pressure range 0.9–1.0, which was attributed to the presence of larger pores (macropores). This structure of the macro/mesopores (Fig. S4) might be formed with irregular aggregate of particles. Generally, high surface area of mesopores increased the probability to contact with substrates. 4 Conclusion In this work, we provided new synthetic method for the formation of imidazolium-based polymer. This synthetic method was simple and green. This novel synthetic method would provide new platform for the formation of the solid supporters and the responding heterogeneous NHC-metal complexes. PImCl and NHC-Pd polymer were successfully synthesized. When this NHC-Pd polymer was employed as a solid catalyst, even with a low catalyst loading, it still demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance for the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction under mild reaction conditions. This NHC-Pd polymer showed good catalytic activity in Suzuki-Miyaura reactions of various aryl bromides with phenylboronic acid. Due to its easy separation, this NHC-Pd polymer can be reused to catalyze Suzuki-Miyaura reaction. coredata.dc:description: Polymers containing the structure of N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) have attracted much interest due to their superior complexing ability to metal ions and good recyclability, which make them promising candidates as solid supporters. Herein, we developed an easy method to synthesize polyimidazolium chloride salt (PImCl) via one-step method in mild conditions. After PImCl was chelated with palladium chloride in 3-chloropyridine, this NHC-Pd polymer was employed as the solid catalyst for Suzuki reactions of aryl bromides and phenylboronic acid. The catalytic activity of the NHC-Pd polymer was high for many different substrates. Moreover, the Suzuki reaction of 4-bromoanisole with phenylboronic acid could be catalyzed by this NHC-Pd polymer in mild conditions. Furthermore, this solid catalyst could be easily isolated by centrifugal separation. After several recycling runs, the catalytic activity decreased little. Compared with the conventional methods, this method was much simpler and more efficient, which showed enormous potential in preparing new heterogeneous supporter of porous polyimidazolium chloride salt.
coredata.dc:title: A simple method for preparing imidazolium-based polymer as solid catalyst for Suzuki-Miyaura reaction
